1126278659289960448.text: Same thing happened to me when wanting to buy an Apple TV. They quoted me 45 min to give them money. I left too.

1126258436725985280.text: Same thing happened to me at Charlotte NC store. A curt “please don’t handle the watches”. In sharp contrast to the rest of the store and prior 18 years.

1126253750488784897.text: Something like this has happened to me, too. I was checking out a couple of the watches on the try-on table when a salesperson told me that I had to make an appointment to try them on. That seems unnecessarily precious.

1126266133206786048.text: Tim’s been reading your keyboard tweets and has had enough.

1126201580884307968.text: Next year will be the year of USB-C on the desktop.

1126196245075243009.text: the race between USB and bluetooth to be really great one day soon is one i am watching with great interest marco tbh

1126185352660692992.text:
I’ve gone from my personal 2017MBP to a work 2015MBP and I understand you better now. Keyboard is amazingly better and that HDMI and MiniDisplay port don’t fail at all.

My daily setup is 2 external monitors and 1 USB-A.

1126144558474059776.text:
The keyboard on the MacBook Pro (mine’s a year or more old) is so fucking annoying and shitty. 

gah. This is my livelihood.

1111690777002795009.text: Also, take a moment to see how Dell has completely whomped Apple when it comes to designing a power brick. Dell’s is a joy, Apple’s is a pain.pic.twitter.com/0k6ToGSNds

1126114979135070210.text:
If my laptop requires Bluetooth, BT must be rock solid (it isn’t, I have to use a 3rd party wired mouse).
If my laptop requires a USB/TB dock then docks must work flawlessly (they do not).
If I need an external monitor (I do), it must work all the time (it doesn’t).

1125444583943548928.text:
I ask because I often get emails or “bug” reports that say, “I have continuous play enabled, but it doesn’t work!”

But what has actually happened, if I ask, is that the person reached the end of one podcast’s episode list, and the behavior since 1.0 has been to stop.

1125444122230382592.text:
Suppose you’re listening to a podcast OUTSIDE of a playlist — just playing one podcast’s episodes. At the end of the last episode, if you have Continuous Play enabled, what should happen?

- Stop (the current behavior)
- Play the next podcast

[Twitter poll]

And I’m kind of unsure that leadership at Apple understands what’s great and important about Macs that we should not lose.

Evolve, change, yes — but not become a supercomputer with its arms tied behinds its back. That’s what I worry about it.

1124435455007764485.text: Moral of the story: no I am not worried one bit about UIKit apps on macOS being 'Mac-like'. Both UIKit, *and* 'Mac-like', are going to evolve

Coder (aka ⁦@marcoarment)⁩: I can’t deal with AV Foundation or Core Audio. Headers and docs give me nothing to go on. It’s so hard.
Boss: Go read the blog of the great Pagliacci. He knows everything there is to know about media frameworks.
Coder: But boss… I am Pagliacci.pic.twitter.com/XLc08gQ5M3

1124342455174823936.text: If you take a year out of iOS development work to work on a Mac app, there are a dozen new frameworks and hundreds of new APIs to catch up on when you get back. Mac developers are not accustomed to this kind of churn, so it's easy to say 'just learn AppKit'

1124342031302701063.text: Interesting discussions about AppKit vs UIKit and devs just being afraid of it, but that's nonsense. The iOS developer platform moves too fast for you to have to take time out to reinvent the wheel to build two completely different UIs. *Apple* struggles with this, never mind us

1124272662681915392.text: Marzipan is gonna be amazing. I know old Mac guard are anxious but this feels like the early days of iPhone to me—poking at the APIs months before they became an SDK, seeing the kinds of things that could be built, etc. I trust Apple to make this the best way to write Mac apps

1124101778214215682.text: Today's marzipanification: @drbarnard's Weather Up (@Weather_Up_)! That was a marathon effort from @bbatsell, but here it is on macOS in all its glory  (beautiful app, too)pic.twitter.com/fdacnoSTRJ

1124002262089699334.text: Jony finally white roomed the App Store.https://twitter.com/brentsimmons/status/1124000622225891328 …

1123989136699023360.text: You can write good or bad apps using any framework. You can write bad AppKit apps today with totally non-standard UI. So long as Apple gives us the tools, and it sounds like they will, I really don’t think it matters if I use an NSView or a UIView to build things.

1123988464083587074.text: Back in 2000, we said apps written using AppKit won’t be Mac-like, NeXTStep apps won’t get the fine Macintosh user interface subtlety like traditional Carbon apps that have been on the platform for decades. It wasn’t true. It’s the people, not the API, that make the difference.

In the last couple of months, I've really got back into RSS.

There's something refreshing about curating a small list of blog subscriptions from folks with consistently high quality content.

It feels more intentional than haphazard discovery of content through social feeds.

1121491774596374530.text:
323: A Slightly Smaller Thumb
http://atp.fm/323 

New T-shirts, potential threats to the podcasting landscape, and the latest Marzipan reports.

1121445260901736450.text: To clarify my stance on this: I've seen enough startups come and go over the years that promise to aggregate RSS blog/podcast content to "elevate the medium". They don't care. Creators are just a commodity to them. They never ask for consent and act like the saviors of a medium.

1121416390047494145.text:
The fact that they call the podcast community “theirs” is rather slimy.

They show no appreciation of what makes podcasts good.

1121407760644616192.text: (I think Spotify has moved to pass-through for the vast majority of shows. Pandora is a re-hoster, though.)

1121383166814687233.text: Kind of wild how these paid podcasting startups manage to fuck up the most basic tenants of podcasting right out of the gatehttps://twitter.com/marcoarment/status/1121370595348889600 …

1121205867054022660.text: We’ll be live in 45 minutes (9 PM EDT), but don’t peel off that screen protector!http://atp.fm/live

1121132411293593600.text: Today begins the #DeleteFBSDK movement. It started with @slopesapp and might include...you?https://www.macobserver.com/columns-opinions/editorial/time-to-delete-facebook-sdk/ …

1121062254009626625.text: It’s pretty simple actually. Podcasts give listeners what they want and are beloved by them. Facebook, Google, etc give advertisers what they want and are bemoaned by their users.

1121018605041270785.text: In other words, the main people that don’t like the limited feature set of podcast distribution are the people who want to monetize it in ways that listeners would hate.https://twitter.com/marcoarment/status/1121017933470289920 …

1121018520970649600.text: Aside from HTTP itself, Podcasts seem to be the only internet tech that comes to mind that still works the way it was originally intended and hasn't been coopted by a large company and then subsequently ruined/made incompatible/etc.

1120890781408137217.text: Apple seemed to need a lot of reminding that the Mac was important. Now, it’s important to remind them *why* the Mac is important, so that they get any coming transitions right. The future is still being written

1120850885180121088.text: @marcoarment @caseyliss @siracusa @jsnell @imyke I propose a RelayFM podcast called MinMax... featuring Marco and Casey... Wirecutter-esque product reviews of a most-expensive-in-class product from Marco, and then the most-affordable-in-class product from Casey... and then swap!

1120752406009139200.text: I will never buy a butterfly keyboard laptop again from Apple. The only way they can regain my trust is with a re-design. Show the customers you’ve heard them, and throw you weight behind this problem and fix it.

1120727758101983232.text: These days whenever I need a little brain break, I find myself making custom watch faces.  This morning’s was a fun astronomy face showing altitude/azimuth of our solar system:pic.twitter.com/747u6TsAyr

1119709859979714560.text:
One of my most controversial software opinions is that your sleep quality and stress level matter far, far more than the languages you use or the practices you follow. Nothing else comes close: not type systems, not TDD, not formal methods, not ANYTHING.

Allow me to explain why.

Me: why can’t you tell me how much I owe, and I’ll just take your word for it?

Gov’t: we’re not allowed to.

Me: why not?

Gov’t: the company that sells you the software you’ll use to figure out for yourself how much you owe us is paying us to not let you.

Me: lolwut

1118141455061671939.text:
Government: You owe us money. It’s called taxes.

Me: How much do I owe?

Gov’t: You have to figure that out.

Me: I just pay what I want?

Gov’t: Oh, no we know exactly how much you owe. But you have to guess that number too.

Me: What if I get it wrong?

Gov’t: You go to prison

1115291153069293569.text:
I had a problem where my computers weren't expensive enough.

Apple to the rescue!

“Ok. We want to buy one. How can we try them on?”

“We have to check you in first.”

“Is there a wait?”

“Yes, but we can’t tell you how long.”

The store wasn’t crowded. Many staffers were standing around talking to each other.

We left instead of waiting.

1126143735828484097.text:
I was going to write a “Fixing the MacBook Pro, Revisited” post, but I think everything I wrote in 2017 still applies today:

- Magic Keyboard w/inverted-T
- More ports to reduce the need for dongles
- Great USB-C hubs
- Touch Bar optional
- Nicer charger

https://marco.org/2017/11/24/fixing-the-macbook-pro …

1126132695476711424.text:
I made automated Linux setup scripts for Ubuntu LTS servers in January.

They’re already broken. Took two hours to fix.

This is the worst side of Linux: you can get something working ONCE, but any automation to do the same thing in the future won’t last very long.

1126106316362190849.text:
A rock-solid-reliable, widely-agreeable keyboard with hardware Esc and inverted-T arrows would do the most good.

Beyond that, less need for unreliable dongles (so more ports, maybe even different kinds!), and more reliable operation with external monitors and/or clamshell mode.https://twitter.com/reneritchie/status/1126105458304081921 …

1126102989654175744.text:
This perspective (a common one) should be most worrisome to Apple:

“The MacBook Pro seems designed for other people’s needs, not mine.”

…especially coming from developers, which Apple has said are their largest category of “pro” users.https://twitter.com/aharden/status/1126100559746957313 …

1126099279645425665.text: And step 0 for winning back web developers is fixing the MacBook Pro, the computer that got us all there in the first place.

1126098607231381505.text:
If you’ve wondered why Microsoft made the VS Code editor, note how many lines go from “First” to “OSX” [sic] to “Visual Studio Code”.

Macs OWNED web development for a decade. But when Apple lost years alienating and neglecting pros, Microsoft had their foot on the gas.https://twitter.com/listonb/status/1125483211100905472 …

1125899453620207617.text: And let me know if I screwed it up this time.https://twitter.com/atpfm/status/1125899268131364865 …

1122317760955129862.text:
Install the App Store version overtop the TestFlight version if you have it. You won’t lose data that way.

TestFlight’s initial Apple-approval process for a new version would’ve taken more time than I had for this feature, so I skipped the beta for this version.https://twitter.com/VarinPrime/status/1122310852558901248 …

1122316975185846277.text:
I actually played with this (since I was already reading the peak data for the clip editor), but couldn’t get it to look good without being really distracting.

Also tried the old FFT bars from Overcast 1.x, but they had the same problem.

I found simpler to be better.https://twitter.com/grahamlampa/status/1122302034974314496 …

1122316536692269056.text:
I don’t think any podcasts exist that use both chapter markers and dynamic ad insertion.

Most big podcast publishers don’t seem to realize chapters exist, and often propose new standards that reinvent functionality they already offer, like showing images or links at timestamps.https://twitter.com/SamTheGeek/status/1122299366662901760 …

1122225314338361344.text:
I tried sending both the video and URL to the share system to see if various apps would do the right thing and share both, but most didn’t. So I offer separate URL and video sharing buttons.

My recommended workflow is to copy the URL, then share the video to wherever, and paste.https://twitter.com/scottaw/status/1122221270009962496 …

1122224146639982592.text:
Clips are file attachments to wherever you’re posting them, so they’ll stay exact.

The web links load the file directly from the publisher each time and seek to the specified timestamp, so if they use DAI with variable-duration ads, they’ll be off by a bit. Another DAI problem.https://twitter.com/tverschoren/status/1122214491247316993 …

1122221759913177091.text:
Yeah, this felt like a good limit for multiple reasons:

- fair use
- longer than that would stretch people’s attention spans in social feeds
- it’s Instagram’s video limithttps://twitter.com/Tom53086/status/1122202258731483136 …

1122220910344318977.text:
I experimented with automatic transcripts from Apple, Google, and other various providers during clip-sharing development. But none were reliably usable.

They’re OK for search-indexing, but not for humans to read. Imagine the way your voicemail transcribes. It’s like that.https://twitter.com/Stuporman/status/1122199624209453056 …

1122187644920897537.text: I suppose this is one of those reasons I should’ve beta-tested this feature. I’ll try to fix it for the next update.https://twitter.com/HoraceHuck/status/1122186931398332416 …

1122186699176652800.text:
And it doesn’t make sense on iOS because almost nobody even knows what version they’re using. Things just change sometimes, and they deal with it.

Quick, what version of Instagram do you use? I have no idea. I just use Instagram. Most iOS apps don’t have meaningful versioning.https://twitter.com/samgrover/status/1122186152843177984 …

1122179576124276736.text:
New to Overcast: Clip sharing!

Read more: https://marco.org/2019/04/27/overcast-clip-sharing …pic.twitter.com/zqqXF4umm7

1121479083903393792.text: (There are lots of other reasons to dislike them, and I’m sure they’ll keep giving us more, but at least this one appears to be resolved.)

1121478686371393542.text:
Confirmed, the @hearluminary podcast-masking proxy URLs are now serving HTTP 302 redirects.

Glad they responded quickly. Should’ve been done properly from the start, but at least they fixed it.

If they don’t pull any more proxying shenanigans, I’d consider this resolved.https://twitter.com/wuchyi/status/1121476592759267328 …

1121437502823387136.text:
Some testing appears to confirm @hearluminary’s claims of 1:1 proxying.

So this should be easy for them to fix: change it to an HTTP redirect, and these problems immediately disappear.

1121426829070487553.text:
Alright, enough Twitter ranting. Let’s see how this plays out. Somebody message me if anything happens.

Off to edit a podcast in which we talk about podcasting, which will be directly downloaded from our servers by the vast majority of our audience using standard podcast apps.

1121425262716039168.text:
That may be the rationale, but if so, nobody ran it by any lawyers first.

And certainly not any podcasters.https://twitter.com/bizzyunderscore/status/1121424899115905030 …

1121424832967651331.text: If @hearluminary is truly 1:1 proxying podcast files and not modifying them, they should be able to switch to HTTP redirection and achieve the same goals as whatever their problematic proxy/CDN is doing.

1121423820261351426.text: There’s also little speed difference to be had in practice even with caching, since most podcasts are already hosted on CDNs.

1121423658990305281.text: It’s not faster if it’s 1:1. That means for each request, a Cloudflare server must fetch the file from the publisher’s servers, then re-serve it to you. It will always be slower, even if only slightly. CDNs are only faster if they cache. https://twitter.com/LukFunk/status/1121422779046400004 …

1121423184325218304.text: I’d like to know that as well. Most programmers recognize that number (86400 seconds per day), and “?ttl=86400” at the end of ATP’s proxied audio URL sure looks like a URL meant to be cached by a CDN for up to 1 day. https://twitter.com/farmerchris/status/1121421879158427649 …

1121421979473653763.text:
I wouldn’t advise that podcasters pull out of @hearluminary over their proxying yet — I’m giving them a short window to change it.

Pulling your show out of a podcast player (which may end up a significant one) shouldn’t be a rash decision.

But if they don’t change? Screw ‘em.

1121421041560162304.text:
Right. HTTP redirection instead of 1:1 proxying would completely solve the problems.

(Although even then, I’m not sure why they need it.)https://twitter.com/joeflateau/status/1121420545407500291 …

1121418925491851264.text:
I can’t think of a good reason to proxy all downloads 1:1 like this.

It won’t add any speed in practice — most downloads will actually be slower — and adds significant costs, will be interpreted as copyright infringement by many lawyers, and makes podcasters want to opt out.

1121417646237523968.text:
Luminary’s responding in this thread, claiming (I think) that they’re proxying, not caching — still re-serving, but making a new request to the publishers’ servers for each request.

If so, that’s still a copyright issue and still breaks most stats, which de-dupe by request IP.https://twitter.com/hearluminary/status/1121404733112111106 …

1121388026360410114.text:
Yup. The podcast economy works on download counts, not RSS subscribers.

Re-hosting platforms (Spotify, Google, formerly Stitcher) prevent each download from being counted properly by the publisher, under-reporting their audience size.

That’s why re-hosting requires opt-ins.https://twitter.com/dloehr/status/1121385808773226496 …

1121378804772081666.text:
“Podcasters whose content is accessible on the free app receive standard data about listeners through their RSS feed.”

What does that mean? Subscriber count in User-Agent? Because that’s irrelevant, and not a replacement for the stats podcasters get from direct audio downloads.https://twitter.com/markelp/status/1121377923771064320 …

1121371294795272192.text: Because when I go here, I hear our @atpfm episode being re-served by a @hearluminary CDN without our permission.https://media.luminarypodcasts.com/v1/media/episode/public/ddb9664c-a770-44d7-a4f1-8e6bbbb78aa0/aHR0cDovL3RyYWZmaWMubGlic3luLmNvbS9hdHBmbS9hdHAzMjIubXAz.mp3?ttl=86400 …

1121370595348889600.text:
Can anyone confirm this? It sure looks like it if this is an API dictionary.

Is @hearluminary re-hosting podcasts without permission on a http://media.luminarypodcasts.com  CDN, thereby bypassing our servers for most downloads and robbing us of stats?

If so, that’s copyright infringement.https://twitter.com/_jakcron/status/1121253491345768448 …

1121200316236619776.text: In this month’s @_RelayFM members-only newsletter: all of the gear on my desk, and why.https://twitter.com/shawnhank/status/1121190195057926144 …

1121182484979441664.text:
If true, it seems likely to me that we’ll have ARM Macs before Intel moves past 14nm.

It’s possible that there will *never* be a Mac with a 10nm Intel CPU. By the time they’re widely available, Apple may have filled all of the applicable roles with ARM models.https://twitter.com/tapbot_paul/status/1121173890057867264 …

1121122147294961665.text:
I don’t think we want the world in which Apple pursued the trademark on “podcast” (they briefly tried, forever ago, but abandoned the effort).

But this is one problem that would solve. You can’t call just anything a Compact Disc, SD Card, USB, etc. because of controlling groups.

1118310149695975434.text: The first 4 minutes of this @chase_reeves video are a masterpiece:https://youtu.be/baLRmbBdoUo

1118227952947351558.text:
Absolutely. As Apple needs more revenue from its services to please investors — a treadmill that never stops — it’ll keep creating huge financial incentives to make its products worse for its customers.

It’s foolish to assume that they’ll practice strong self-control forever.https://twitter.com/tofias/status/1118226582689275905 …

1118227474528329730.text:
It makes you one type of person. But it’s a mistake to assume that there aren’t a lot of people with different needs and priorities.

It’s unwise to speculate on what other people DON’T need.https://twitter.com/thomaspaine/status/1118225729429237760 …

1118224121656070144.text:
These need not be mutually exclusive.

There’s nothing wrong with curated playlists and other automatic features.

There’s also nothing wrong with offering power-user headroom for the people who want to actually drive their computer instead of being taken for a ride.https://twitter.com/alexbrooks/status/1118204247408041984 …

1118138879943507968.text:
It’s not me — it’s our kid.

(Which should surprise nobody.)https://twitter.com/rjonesy/status/1118138463914725383 …

1118135997596864514.text:
I don’t think the honey-roasted peanuts in the grinders (PLU 8313) are the same as the ones in the bulk bin (PLU 5932).

Our store once inadvertently filled the grinder with the 5932 nuts, and the resulting peanut butter was noticeably different and worse — less sugar, I think.

1118135550421229568.text:
I’ve also gotten a response from Whole Foods on #longlive8313 that doesn’t conflict with this:

They’re “changing suppliers” for the honey-roasted peanuts in the grinder, which has resulted in “temporary” unavailability, but they’ll be back.https://twitter.com/rjonesy/status/1117979723831947264 …

1117880097434824704.text:
Tip on oil separation in peanut butter: keep any backstock in the fridge except the active jar/tub.

The separation doesn’t happen at fridge temperatures, so you effectively pause it until the last minute.https://twitter.com/troygilbert/status/1117851998202814464 …

1117842986891730944.text: Yes. The best jelly I’ve found is Tiptree raspberry seedless: https://www.tiptree.com/index.php/raspberry-seedless-conserve.html …https://twitter.com/smilespray/status/1117840223793238018 …

1117827209320906752.text:
Any peanut butter whose ingredients contain another oil is also wrong.

They remove and sell the more valuable peanut oil, replacing it with something cheaper like palm oil.

Good peanut butter’s ingredients should only be peanuts, salt, and an optional sweetener. No other oils.

1117826430988161024.text: (Remember the good old days of Twitter, when all we needed to talk or read about was bullshit like this?)

1117826091123650560.text:
The @WholeFoods peanut-butter grinders have taught us a valuable lesson: “crunchy” and “smooth” are bullshit.

Smooth is too smooth, and crunchy is just smooth with some peanut pieces mixed in.

The grinders yield a sort of large-grain smooth, a perfect medium between the two.

1117821310397292545.text:
Is the @WholeFoods honey-roasted peanut butter from the fresh grinders (PLU 8313) gone for good? 

Our two local stores haven’t had it for over a month, and it’s our family favorite, even though it’s probably more sugar than peanuts. Nothing else is as good. #longlive8313

1117410857196118016.text: I’m particularly proud of the iTunes-breakup segment on this week’s @atpfm. If you love computers that empower you to be a power user, give this a listen (start at 30:12, runs about an hour):https://overcast.fm/+CdQwKWV0/30:12

1116716097837912064.text: If that’s true, that’s definitely the wrong decision.https://twitter.com/rjonesy/status/1116715435481817089 …

1115793693406003201.text: I love this kind of power and customization, and it’s the kind of thing we’re losing with the dominance of iOS itself and the invasion of the iOS mindset into macOS:https://indiestack.com/2019/04/toggle-system-grayscale-mode/ …

1115693595921735680.text:
I get a family-history-screening MRI every 5 years. How society has advanced:

It used to cost $2500. Now it’s only $1200, but this is the first time insurance refused to cover it.

It used to take 45 minutes. This one took only 15, while my electric car charged outside for free.

1115604639192211456.text:
Will the greatness of the new desktops come to the notebooks as well?

It didn’t come to the Air, but the Air was only half-new, really — it felt like a rushed mishmash of the 12” and Escape to fix the Escape’s failure to replace the old Air.

I’m hoping that’s answered in 2019.

1115603638976532482.text:
I suspect they also had a sort of branch misprediction a few years ago, and the Mac pipeline had to start over.

Abject neglect for a while, then a big misstep in 2016, then a pipeline flush.

The totally-new Macs since then (iMac Pro, Mac Mini) have been fantastic.

1115602417662304256.text:
A big part of it is that it’s much more complex than we think, or external factors (like Intel) screw them a lot.

But I bet a much bigger part of the problem is that they just don’t prioritize Mac hardware (or software) enough.

It gets good, eventually… and it moves glacially.https://twitter.com/stevex/status/1115601119919476737 …

1115601617829548033.text: “This week’s Ming-Chi Kuo report has been wrongly reported by other publications a few times based on mistranslations. The previously-reported ~16.5-inch MacBook Pro is not delayed — or at least that is not what Kuo is claiming here.”https://twitter.com/bzamayo/status/1115600929632350208 …

1115331259868250112.text:
Sometimes, success brings complacency and hubris that takes a good kick in the ass to overcome.

The 2013 Mac Pro and the reception to the Touch Bar were small kicks in the ass, but I think the mass failure of the butterfly keyboard has been the big one that they needed.https://twitter.com/michaelflux/status/1115291879803719680 …

1115330122851278849.text:
I’m glad they tried, too. The butterfly keyboard was an appropriate experiment for the 12” MacBook, and only that.

Whoever made the call to expand it to ALL notebooks, then kept shipping them for the next four years despite the problems, shouldn’t have a job at Apple anymore.https://twitter.com/Raddock/status/1115287416288497666 …

1115329327443390465.text:
1. “Apple never does X” rarely precludes them from doing something. They often surprise us.

2. I don’t think they’ve ever had a product flaw of the magnitude and severity of the butterfly keyboard.

They have ample motivation to correct this years-long mistake.https://twitter.com/scharf_10/status/1115286149671661568 …

1115326566580531200.text: Someone go check on the beer and sausage place and the vegan Indian place down the street! They’re all we have left.

1115326360518524928.text: The service may be marginally worse as a result.https://twitter.com/bwebster/status/1115309315756253184 …

1115286021413986305.text:
I hope Apple has learned their lesson that we don’t really need them to revolutionize keyboards.

They unnecessarily revolutionized themselves into a world of pain, making massive regressions in the most important functional areas, all to solve problems we didn’t really have.https://twitter.com/podperson/status/1115279100338479104 …

1115276732779638785.text:
I have a horrible track record with Apple predictions, usually in the direction of being overly optimistic.

But I think 2019 is the year we’ll see the replacement for the butterfly keyboard, and I bet it’ll be a low-profile scissor design, much more like the Magic Keyboard.https://twitter.com/_andrewmartin_/status/1115275790764187648 …

1115272916751605762.text: Maybe 2019 will bring the triumphant return of the Esc key.https://twitter.com/_inside/status/1115271257191219200 …

1115053664375275520.text:
I am indeed extra hyped for this WWDC.

I haven’t heard any specifics, but I’ve heard from multiple sources that this is going to be a big one.https://twitter.com/vmachiel/status/1114954888897814529 …

1114680927622447104.text: It’s obvious bullshit, and the real reason is obviously not what they said it was.

1114680693907492870.text:
Another way to think of it: Would ANY of Netflix’s customers think this was the right call?

“Oh, they can’t ensure that it looks ‘right’ on my TV? Then I shouldn’t be able to do this at all. I’m sure glad they stopped me before I saw potentially non-ideal picture quality.”

1114679812579307525.text:
Media outlets aren’t being critical enough of Netflix here.

Their argument is effectively “We can’t tell which TV you’re using, so you aren’t allowed to send video to TVs anymore.”

It’s complete bullshit, and an uncharacteristically customer-punishing move from Netflix.https://twitter.com/MacRumors/status/1114598837010571265 …

1114355164138418176.text: Nest needs a Spouse Away mode that automatically raises the temperature by four degrees at night whenever your spouse is out of town.

1114237702336065536.text:
The @MrSpeakers Aeon Flow Closed headphones are phenomenal.

VERY smooth, present midrange sings with vocals and guitars (like the HE-6!). Bass and treble are a bit light, but not fatally so.

Amazing sound for a closed-back design. Strong amp required.

https://www.mrspeakers.com/headphones-22/aeon.html …

1114134477238882304.text:
I’d feel this way if they hadn’t already spent such a long time ceding the high-end, professional market to competitors.

They haven’t made a versatile, reliable, compelling Mac Pro since 2010. The last reliable MacBook Pro was 2015. And macOS itself has been neglected for years.https://twitter.com/jeffventura/status/1114131581692674050 …

1114129332228771841.text:
I’d be disappointed that they’d be abandoning a lot of customers’ needs.

But I’m really happy with my iMac Pro, and between it and the new Mac Mini, a lot of pro needs are covered. So I’d be mostly OK with it as long as the iMac Pro and Mac Mini kept getting great updates.https://twitter.com/thewinger/status/1114028955516981248 …
